## <span style="font-size:80%">Making Sense of Variables: Categorical vs. Numerical</span> {.smaller}

::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Categorical Variables (Qualitative)**

::: incremental
- **Utility**: Can count frequencies, mode, or proportions
      
      - Classify patients, samples, or conditions into distinct categories rather than measuring a numerical quantity
      - N.B.: no meaningful mathematical operations - add, subtract, or average

- **Examples**:
    
    - Blood type: A, B, AB, O
    - Cancer stage: Stage I, Stage II, Stage III, Stage IV
    - Genetic variant: Present / Absent

:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Numerical Variables (Quantitative)**

::: incremental
- **Utility**: Allows for a wide range of statistical analyses, including: measures of central tendency (mean, median), variability (standard deviation), and associations (correlation, regression)

- **Examples**:
    
    - White blood cell count (cells/µL)
    - Serum glucose level (mg/dL)
    - Tumor size (cm)
:::
:::
:::
::: footer
:::

## <span style="font-size:80%">Definition: Categorical Data</span> {.smaller}

::: columns

::: {.column width="100%"}
::: incremental

- Variables that represent discrete groups, classes, or categories, rather than numeric values 

- **No inherent numeric meaning**: 
  
  - The numbers may represent codes but do not imply order or magnitude unless explicitly ordinal.
  - Variables that have an inherent or coded magnitude

- **Discrete values**: Each observation belongs to one (or more) categories
  
  - Categorical data is visualized to compare frequencies, proportions, or relationships between groups

- **Single-label or multi-label**
  
  - Observations may belong to one category (exclusive) or multiple categories (non-exclusive)

- In biomedical research these values describe characteristics, conditions, or classifications of patients, samples, or biological entities
:::
:::

::: incremental

## <span style="font-size:80%">Properties of categorical variables</span> {.smaller}

::: columns

::: {.column width="100%"}

**Type (binary / nominal / ordinal)**

::: incremental

- **Binary**: Two categories

  - Example: Disease status (Yes/No), Gender (Male/Female)


- **Nominal**: More than two categories with no order

  - Example: Blood type (A, B, AB, O), Tissue type (liver, kidney, lung)


- **Ordinal**: Categories with a natural order

  - Example: Cancer stage (I, II, III, IV), Pain severity (mild, moderate, severe)

:::

## <span style="font-size:80%">Properties of categorical variables</span> {.smaller}

::: columns

::: {.column width="100%"}

**Cardinality (number of distinct categories)**

::: incremental

- **Low cardinality**:
  
  - Smoking status → [Current, Former, Never]: 3 levels

- **Medium cardinality**:
  
  - Cancer type → [Breast, Lung, Colorectal, Prostate] :  ~10-20 levels

- **High cardinality**:

  - Patient ID → each patient is unique → thousands of categories
  - Genetic mutation identifiers → potentially tens of thousands of distinct variants

## <span style="font-size:80%">Properties of categorical variables</span> {.smaller}

::: columns

::: {.column width="100%"}

**Exclusivity (single vs. multi-label)**

::: incremental

- **Single-label (mutually exclusive comparison)** 
  
  - Comparison of disjointed groups
  - Patients or samples are classified into one group only


  - Examples:
      
      - Disease stage (I, II, III, IV)
      - Blood type (A, B, AB, O)
      - Clinical trial arm (treatment vs. control)

**Exclusivity (single vs. multi-label)**

::: incremental

- **Single-label (mutually exclusive comparison)** 
  
  - Summarize and display data

      - Bar charts → show proportions across disjoint groups
      - Kaplan-Meier survival curves → one curve per exclusive group

## <span style="font-size:80%">Properties of categorical variables</span> {.smaller}

::: columns

::: {.column width="100%"}

**Exclusivity (single vs. multi-label)**

::: incremental

- **Multi-label (non-exclusive)** 
  
  - Patients/samples may belong to multiple categories at once
  - Biomedical datasets are often multi-label in practice, since diseases and molecular features overlap
  - **Examples**:
      
      - Comorbidities (diabetes + hypertension + COPD)
      - Mutational profiles (TP53 + KRAS + EGFR)
      - Symptoms (fever + cough + fatigue)
      
:::

## <span style="font-size:80%">Summary</span> {.smaller}

::: columns

::: {.column width="100%"}



::: incremental

- **Definition & role:**

  - Categorical variables classify patients/samples (not numeric scales) 
  - Summarized to show counts/percentages or group relationships
  
- **Type drives interpretation**

  - Binary (yes/no)
  - Nominal (unordered classes)
  - Ordinal (ordered severity or stage)

## <span style="font-size:80%">Summary</span> {.smaller}

::: columns

::: {.column width="100%"}



::: incremental

- **Cardinality matters: **

  - Low (e.g., smoking status)
  - Medium (cancer types)
  - High (mutation IDs) influences grouping/lumping decisions before plotting

  
- **Exclusivity shapes the display:**

  - Single-label: compare disjoint groups (e.g., bar charts; survival curves with one line per group)
  - Multi-label: show overlaps or patterns (e.g., Venn/UpSet for intersections)
